title: Strong economies need profitable banks, says Wilson
text:
“On our numbers if the banks passed on the entire last three interest rate cuts we estimate that the banking sector’s earnings would be $4.5 billion to $6 billion lower."

AFIC boss Mark Freeman: "Big banks don’t own big banks, Australians own the big banks." Wayne Taylor

Mr Wilson has been joined by a group of stakeholders including Australian Foundation Investment Company managing director Mark Freeman and Bendigo and Adelaide Bank chairman Robert Johanson who have dismissed the Prime Minister's claims as misguided and simplistic.

'Australians own the big banks'

AFIC managing director Mark Freeman said the big banks should be allowed to make an acceptable return on their investment and attacking their profitability was an attack on the earnings of ordinary Australians.

“When they talk about big banks, big banks don’t own big banks, Australians own the big banks, and if you take away the profitability of the Australian banks you are actually taking that profit from Australian shareholders,” he said.

As of September 30, the big four banks represent 22.6 per cent of AFIC’s portfolio, worth approximately $1.7 billion. CBA, the company’s biggest holding, is worth $639 million alone.

Mr Freeman said increased capital requirements, compliance and regulatory costs were to blame and “each year they tack on more and more costs”.

Advertisement

Banks take risks and needed to deliver an acceptable return on capital in order to remain investable, Mr Freeman said.

Bendigo Bank chairman Robert Johanson said bank boards needed to push back against Canberra. AAP

“The interest rate cuts have a significant impact on their margins and their returns and they need to protect the interests of shareholders.”

"We are going into uncertain times here and during the global financial crisis many Australian businesses required recapitalisation, and Australian people having confidence that they are investing in a good sound businesses was a part of that.''

Shared pressures

Outgoing Bendigo and Adelaide Bank chairman Robert Johanson said all banks were facing the same pressures.

He said the bank carefully considered its range of stakeholders including shareholders, employees, borrowers and savers every time.

“Every marginal dollar we get – it’s a contest as to which of those stakeholders get that dollar,” Mr Johanson said.

Advertisement

Mr Johanson said shareholders needed to be protected too, backing AFIC’s observation about their willingness to contribute to capital raisings during the GFC.

He said it was up to the bank boards to push back against the government’s populist bank bashing but said they would be reluctant following the bollocking dished out by the Hayne royal commission.

APRA chairman Wayne Byers said our banks compared favorably to those in Europe. Louie Douvis

“You can understand why the prime minister might accuse the banks of profiteering for not passing it on, but it is the responsibility of bank boards to say ‘No, we are responsible for running a business that survives through those political cycles and the news cycle’.”

Mr Johanson also pointed out the irony in being told by Canberra to keep the loans flowing.

“The treasurer is out there saying ‘We want you to lend money’. These are the same institutions that a year or two ago were said to be out of control and had to be reined in and restricted because it’s a feeding frenzy out there and people are getting inappropriate loans.”

The support for strong banks backed the position of Australia’s chief banking regulator, who last month drew a direct line between the strength of the banks and the overall health of the economy.

Australian Prudential Regulation Authority chairman Wayne Byres accepted in a September speech that the return on equity of Australian banks was higher than elsewhere but said this was no cause for alarm.

Advertisement

The return on equity of Australian banks reached a high of 20 times before the global financial crisis and fell to around 10 times in the aftermath. They recovered strongly and more recently eased to around 12 times, he said.

European banks on the other hand struggled both during the GFC and in its aftermath, Mr Byers said. They are still yet to recover and he noted many were barely able to deliver an ROE of more than five times.

While strong banks helped facilitate strong economies the reverse was also true, presenting a risk at a time when Australian banks faced considerable headwinds, Mr Byers said.

“Australia’s ongoing economic prosperity has therefore been supported by a functioning banking system, intermediating savings and credit within the economy as needed,” Mr Byers said.

“In contrast, parts of Europe continue to suffer from a banking system that remains fragile, and in places heavily dependent on on-going public sector support in one shape or form.”

'Not a good outcome'

But Treasurer Josh Frydenberg was not backing down.

"The banks have decided to put their profits before their customers, and that’s not a good outcome for their customers or the economy," he said in a statement on Tuesday.

Advertisement

He said the government was implementing policies to increase competition to ensure that consumers can get a better deal.

"The government is making significant progress on empowering customers to make informed decisions with the passage of the Consumer Data Right and expanding the credit reporting regime."

He said the Consumer Data Right allowed customers to securely transfer their banking data to other service providers in order to solicit the best possible deal.

"The government now requires the banks to appear before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics each year, giving them the opportunity to transparently account for their decision making and how they balance the needs of borrowers, savers, shareholders and the wider community.”

with John Kehoe
description: The fund manager who helped the Morrison government win the unwinnable election says attacks on the banks for profiteering are wrong.
